segments.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso mahāsamuddato dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni uddharitāni.
segments.en: “Mendicants, suppose a man was to draw up two or three drops of water from the ocean.

segments.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatāni, yaṃ vā mahāsamudde udakan”ti?
segments.en: Which is more: the two or three drops drawn out or the water in the ocean?”

segments.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ, yadidaṃ—mahāsamudde udakaṃ; appamattakāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatāni.
segments.en: “Sir, the water in the ocean is certainly more. The two or three drops drawn out are tiny.

segments.pli: Saṅkhampi na upenti, upanidhampi na upenti, kalabhāgampi na upenti mahāsamudde udakaṃ upanidhāya dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatānī”ti.
segments.en: Compared to the water in the ocean, it can’t be reckoned or compared, it’s not even a fraction.”
“In the same way, for a noble disciple …
That’s why you should practice meditation …”

suttaplex.blurb: As a few drops of water compared to the ocean, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.
